verses.verse: A certain man was sick, Lazarus of Bethany, which was the town of Mary and her sister Martha.
It was Mary who anointed the Lord with ointment and wiped his feet with her hair, whose brother Lazarus was sick.
Then his sisters sent for him, saying, "Lord! See, your dear friend is sick."
When Jesus heard [this], he said, "This sickness is not to [lasting] death but for the glory of God, that the Son of God might be glorified by it."
Jesus loved Martha, her sister, and Lazarus.
Therefore when he had heard that he was sick, he remained there in that same place where he was for two more days.
Then after this he said to the disciples, "Let us go into Judea again."
The disciples said to him, "Rabbi, the Jews were just seeking to stone you, and you are going back there again?"
Jesus answered, Aren't there twelve hours in the day? If someone walks in the day, he does not stumble, because he sees the light of this world.
"But if someone walks at night, he stumbles, because there is no light in him."
He said these things, and then said to them, "Our friend Lazarus sleeps, but I go, so I can wake him up from sleep."
Then his disciples said, "Lord, if he is sleeping, he will get well."
J, however, spoke of his death, but they thought he spoke about restful sleep.
And so Jesus told them plainly, "Lazarus is dead.
"And for your sakes I'm glad I wasn't there, so that you may believe. Nevertheless let us go to him."
Then Thomas (called the twin) said to his fellow disciples, "Let's go, too, so we can die with him."
When Jesus arrived, he found that he already had been in the grave four days.
Now Bethany was close to Jerusalem, about 15 stades [about two miles] away,
And many Jews came to Martha and Mary, so they could comfort them about their brother.
As soon as Martha heard that Jesus was coming, she went and met him, but Mary stayed seated in the house.
Then Martha said to Jesus, "Lord, if you had been here, my brother would not have died,
but I know that even now, whatever you ask God, God will give [it] to you."
Jesus said to her, "Your brother will rise again."
Martha said to him, "I know that he will rise again in the resurrection at the last day."
Jesus said to her, "I am the resurrection and the life. Even if one who believes in me dies, he will live,
and all who live and believe in me will never die. Do you believe this?"
She said to him, "Yes, Lord, I have believed that you are the Christ, the Son of God, who is coming into the world."
And having said this she went back and called for her sister Martha telling her in private, "The Teacher is here and calls for you."
After she heard [this], she got up quickly and came to him,
for Jesus had not yet come into the town but was at the place where Martha met him.
Then the Jews, who were with her in the house comforting her, saw her get up quickly and leave, they followed her saying, "She goes to the grave to mourn."
When Mary came to where Jesus was, she collapsed at his feet, saying to him, "Lord, if you had been here, my brother would not have died."
Then Jesus after seeing her crying and the Jews with her also crying, he groaned in the spirit and was deeply moved.
He said, "Where did you lay him?" They said to him, "Lord, come and see."
Jesus wept.
Then the Jews said, "Look, how much he loved him!"
But some of them said, "Couldn't this man who opened the eyes of the blind also have kept this man from dying"?
Then Jesus again groaning in himself came to the tomb. It was a tomb with stone lying against it.
Jesus said, "Remove the stone." Martha, the dead man's sister, said to him, Lord, by now he stinks, for he has been [there] four days."
Jesus said to her, "Didn't I tell you that if you would believe, you would see the glory of God?"
So they removed the stone from where the dead lay. Jesus' eyes lifted up, and he said, "Father, I thank you that you have heard me.
"I know that you always hear me, but for the sake of the people standing here I said [this], so that they may believe that you have sent me."
And after he said this he shouted with a loud voice, "Lazarus, come here."
He, who had been dead, came out, bound hand and foot with grave cloths and his face had a handkerchief tied around it. Jesus said to them, "Loose him, and let him go."
Then many of the Jews who had come to Mary and had seen the things, which Jesus did, believed in him.
But some of them went back to the Pharisees and told them what Jesus had done.
Then the chief priests and Pharisees assembled the Council and said, "What are we going to do, for this man does many miracles?
"If we let him alone, everyone will believe in him, and the Romans will come and remove our place and nation."
One of them, Caiaphas, who was high priest that year, said, "All of you know nothing,
or even realize that it is better for us that one man should die for the people and not that the whole nation should be destroyed."
He didn't speak this from himself, but being High Priest that year he prophesied that Jesus was going to die for that nation,
and not only for that nation but that he would also gather the children of God who were scattered abroad.
So from that day, they followed the counsel to kill him.
As a result Jesus no longer walked openly among the Jews but went from there to a place near the wilderness to a city called Ephraim, and he stayed there with his disciples.
The Jew's Passover was approaching, and many went up from the country to Jerusalem before the Passover to ceremonially purify themselves.
They were looking for Jesus and kept saying to one another as they stood in the Temple, "What do you think? Will he come to the festival?"
Now the chief priests and Pharisees had given an order that if any knew where he was, he should report it so they could arrest him.
